Award.AwardTitle: Coherent Super-Resolution Optical Microscopy for Enhanced Image Resolution and Speed

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to increase the resolving power and the image acquisition speed, of super-resolution fluorescence microscopy by about an order of magnitude (to 5-10nm). Resolution in conventional photoactivatable-localization microscopy is limited by the localization precision, which, in turn is proportional to 1/sqrt(N), where N is the number of collected photons. In the proposed approach, we can achieve localization precision that is proportional to 1/N. This is achieved by: (1) reduction in the effective size of the point-spread function (PSF) as a result of a novel grating system, (2) increase in the number of detected photons due to interference with a high intensity reference wave and (3) utilization of phase information in addition to the intensity of the signals using a novel optical correlator for optical filtering.

The intellectual merit arises from the potential acquisition of fluorescence images with macro-molecular (sub-5nm) resolution enabled by a relatively simple addition to conventional confocal microscopes. The transformative nature of the proposed technique is a result of the higher resolution and faster imaging, which will elucidate the fundamental interactions between proteins and sub-cellular nanostructures with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution. Such mechanistic understanding will prove to be essential for future advancements in biology.

The broader impacts of this project include (1) training of the scientific workforce via an innovative, inter-disciplinary course, (2) recruitment of under-represented students via a hands-on demonstration module to be utilized at 3 large outreach events, and (3) widespread dissemination via commercialization of the subject technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to increase the resolving power and the image acquisition speed, of super- resolution fluorescence microscopy (e.g., photoactivatable-localization microscopy ? PALM) by about an order of magnitude (to below 5nm).

Diffraction limits the ability of an optical imaging system to resolve details due to the finite size of the image of a point object, a principle discovered by Ernst Abbe. Extensive research was conducted in order to overcome this limit using far-field and near-field approaches. Two prominent super-resolution modalities are STED/RESOLFT, which use stimulated emission or depletion of the ground state to limit fluorescence excitation to a small spot in the middle of the excitation beam; and PALM/STORM, which use stochastic excitation of well separated fluorophores and localization algorithms.

In this project, we pursued two distinct approaches to increase the performance of localization microscopy. First, we used self-interference between the signal photons to create additional information on the sensor plane, and performing localization based on this patterned signal allowed us to enhance resolution. Our results showed that improvement in localization error of a single emitter can be obtained using a grating interferometer in the detection path. A phase encoding element that will change the phase slope is required in that case to gain improvement in localization performance. We concluded that at a background photon count of 10 photons per pixel, even when the fringes do not move with respect to the camera, the localization error is smaller than the Gaussian case, when the PSF is modulated. This is indeed helpful in the case of our current system, since the grating interferometer imposes interference fringes that are not moving with respect to the camera plane. As we have seen earlier this is a result of background photons that do not interfere, unlike the signal itself. An interfering background will occur when the sources of the background are reflections of the laser when scattering object is tracked. This could be from the optics or the sample. A non-interfering background will occur when the background comes from ambient light or from auto-fluorescence. One example of such a scenario is when one wishes to track a scattering object in auto-fluorescing environment such as cells. A slightly different application is when one would like to track a single emitter on top of a fluorescent signal coming from the sample. In this case, in terms of the localization error, the fluorescent signal reduces the performance of the system. However, since this fluorescence signal does not interfere, by tracking a scattering object, we can retain the low localization error, since the background influence is eliminated.

In the second advancement, we have taken an approach based on point-spread function (PSF) engineering. We have developed a silicon oxide phase plate (manufactured at the University of Utah Nano-Fabrication facility) that induces a wavelength-dependent PSF when placed in the Fourier plane of a microscope. We have dubbed it the ?clover? PSF because it looks like a four-leaf clover. While others have done similar experiment, to our knowledge we are the first to use a simple dielectric phase plate in this way. In contrast to using a liquid crystal spatial light modulator, our dielectric element is polarization insensitive. This allows us to avoid discounting the photon-budget caused by splitting and polarizing the signal. Additionally, our design is simple, which we believe will extend its utility in the future to many different areas of research. Our results indicate that the clover PSF is sensitive to wavelength, while maintaining spatial localization precision for photon-counts that are within those of dyes used in LM.

Four PhD (one woman) students have been graduated, who were associated with this project. Two post-doctoral scientists were also trained during this project. Three of these students are currently employed in industry, while one is in academia. Numerous undergraduate students worked on sub-topics related to this project primarily under the REU umbrella. 

Our approach explored a completely novel approach to enhancing resolution both in space and in spectrum within localization microscopy. We showed experimentally that self-interference of the signal beam can indeed provide enhanced spatial resolution under realistic noise conditions, which was originally predicted by information theory. In addition, we showed that by optimal PSF engineering, spectral resolution is possible without compromising spatial resolution.

The advancement in knowledge created during this project will enable multi-color, 3D fast nanoscale microscopy of living cells. Such a capability will inevitably lead to new discoveries in biology. Our system will be made available to users in academia and industry, enabling early adoption. The proposed project trained multiple PhD students (including one woman), and expose several undergraduates to exciting summer research. The proposed research was intrinsically interdisciplinary.
